Subject: Re: [neat] Re: General Game Playing
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=151231063; y=qPoA7OtH71DsRy8smDGoSycRR2S1CQ0pZZoDgu_hmuj7rw

Hi Ken,

> Sounds like this can be interesting but I'm also wondering a few
> details.  So let's say you get a spec, what exactly do you do next?

We parse the spec and turn it into basically a state machine that we can 
feed inputs (player moves) to and read outputs (new game state) from. Also 
we set up helper functions that can be used to generate all valid moves 
from a certain game state. Finally we extract some relevant information 
about the kinds of things that can constitute the game state, and use that 
information to fix the input layer size of our neural nets.

> Do you get to change some code around or add a new fitness function or
> perhaps sensor/output combos appropriate to that spec?  Or is it
> completley plug and play and you have a totally generic architecture?

Completely plug and play, we get a spec, and weeks later :P once evolution 
is done we have some players.

So one of the cool things about the system is that there are already a lot 
of games for it, and once we release our GDL->NEAT bridge it should be 
usable with really any NE system.

> Interesting, thanks Charles.  So if you get a novel game and right
> away need to play it with no prior experience, how can an
> evolutionary system be prepared for that?

The short answer is coevolution. A game has a certain number of players. 
We establish populations for each player and let them have at each other 
coevolutionarily. Since we don't know what game we will be learning before 
hand, this seems like the most obvious approach. Of course, there are tons 
of tricky details using coevolution (in particular I don't know of any 
research offhand that coevolves more than two populations simultaneously), 
but we're making progress.

> Are you trying to evolve a single neural network that can play any game?

No, for now we're just evolving from scratch every time we receive a new 
specification. One of the interesting research issues that comes up in GGP 
though is whether or not we can use some cool developmental systems jazz 
to evolve an "embryo" player which is an optimal starting genome for any 
kind of game (encapsulating information that is useful for a broad range 
of human-designed games). The idea is that we obtain the embryo by playing 
all the games, and then specialize it later to play a specific game. Its 
really unclear how this can be done, but thats what makes it such an 
interesting research problem.

Does that clear everything up?

Joe


-- 

Joseph Reisinger
http://www.cs.utexas.edu/~joeraii
